Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement to sit in judgement of other local community for the way it judges citizens. The Dutch seem to understand the need to preserve their own culture by recognizing one extended family. Is this a battle for acceptability in the larger world? River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well tended crow's-nest perches aside.
But there's a strange lack of focus and dullness in the characterization - we see them falling in to battle, but there's very little here by way of independent thought, or thought of any variety. Overstretched, and underwritten.

The Bone Snatcher is about a group miners who go on a search for a missing crew of miners in the Namib Desert. When the find them, the crew are found in an area with spikes with feeding tubes going all throughout the place and several skeletons and bodies, including two of the members of the original crew of the vehicle who found this place. Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is clearly a throwback to the 80's, has some decent fight scenes, and is ultimately enjoyable to watch if you're not looking for anything other than an action movie.
